questions.question: What does SDLC stand for in software development?
questions.explanation: SDLC is the acronym for Software Development Life Cycle.

questions.question: Which is the first step in the Object-Oriented SDLC process?
questions.explanation: The starting phase of SDLC is Requirements Gathering.

questions.question: Which of the following represents object-oriented analysis output?
questions.explanation: CRC cards capture classes, responsibilities, and collaborations during OO analysis.

questions.question: What does CRC stand for in CRC cards?
questions.explanation: CRC stands for Class, Responsibility, Collaboration.

questions.question: Which phase includes drawing class diagrams in SDLC?
questions.explanation: Class diagrams are produced during the Design phase.

questions.question: Which of these is not a valid diagram used in object-oriented design?
questions.explanation: Pie Diagram is not used in OO design.

questions.question: What technique is used to identify objects and responsibilities from requirements?
questions.explanation: Noun/Verb analysis extracts candidate classes (nouns) and responsibilities (verbs).

questions.question: In noun/verb analysis, nouns usually become:
questions.explanation: Nouns and noun phrases typically map to classes.

questions.question: Which of these is a rule for eliminating a noun in noun/verb analysis?
questions.option_e: e. Noun is repeated in verbs
questions.explanation: Meta-language terms are outside the system and are eliminated.

questions.question: Which one of these is outside the system scope in a library system?
questions.explanation: Librarian represents an external actor, not an internal class.

questions.question: In a DVD rental system, which of the following is an attribute?
questions.explanation: Fine is a property describing a penalty and thus an attribute.

questions.question: What is the purpose of CRC cards?
questions.option_c: c. Defining class behaviors and collaborators
questions.explanation: CRC cards define Class, Responsibilities, and Collaborations.

questions.question: Where is the class name written in a CRC card?
questions.explanation: The top of the card is reserved for the class name.

questions.question: What part of CRC card explains the actions a class performs?
questions.explanation: Responsibilities list the actions a class can perform.

questions.question: A collaborator in a CRC card is:
questions.option_a: a. A superclass of the class
questions.option_b: b. A method of the class
questions.option_c: c. A class that helps complete responsibilities
questions.option_d: d. A synonym of the class
questions.explanation: Collaborators are other classes that a class interacts with to fulfill its responsibilities.

questions.question: Which type of class handles communication with the user or system boundary?
questions.explanation: Boundary classes manage interactions between the system and external actors.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an Entity class in a library system?
questions.explanation: Book represents core data and is thus an entity class.

questions.question: Which class controls how other classes interact and handles business logic?
questions.explanation: Control classes coordinate workflows and enforce business rules.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a class type in analysis classes?
questions.option_e: e. All of the above are valid
questions.explanation: Abstract classes are an implementation detail, not an analysis-class category.

questions.question: What is the main function of control classes?
questions.option_c: c. Enforce logic and handle flow
questions.explanation: Control classes implement use-case logic and coordinate interactions.

questions.question: Which of the following responsibilities is most likely found in a Book class?
questions.explanation: Borrow book is a behavior directly associated with a Book entity.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely a collaborator of a Book class?
questions.explanation: Member collaborates with Book when borrowing or returning.

questions.question: In the online order system, which of the following is not a valid class?
questions.explanation: Address is an attribute of Customer, not a separate analysis class.

questions.question: In CRC, which of the following is least likely to be a responsibility of the Customer class?
questions.explanation: Payment validation is a concern of a control or payment class, not Customer.

questions.question: What would be the best boundary class for handling user login?
questions.explanation: LoginForm is an interface element for user authentication.

questions.question: In noun-verb analysis, what kind of word typically becomes a method?
questions.explanation: Verbs describe actions and map to methods.

questions.question: Which rule applies when "Faculty" is eliminated during noun filtering?
questions.explanation: Faculty is part of the real world context but not within system scope.

questions.question: In the DVD rental system, which of these is a valid class?
questions.explanation: Unregistered member is an actor with distinct behaviors.

questions.question: In a CRC card, who should be listed under "Collaborators" for the class Order?
questions.explanation: Order collaborates with Item, User, and Payment to process an order.

questions.question: What is the main responsibility of a control class like ReservationHandler?
questions.explanation: Control classes coordinate business logic such as reservations.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a suitable CRC collaborator for Payment?
questions.explanation: DeliveryService is unrelated to payment processing.

questions.question: In CRC analysis, which action is associated with a RegisteredMember?
questions.explanation: Registered members can borrow DVDs under specified rules.

questions.question: In the CRC card layout, which section would contain “Return Book”?
questions.explanation: Return Book is an action, so it goes under Responsibilities.

questions.question: Why are CRC cards useful in early stages of system design?
questions.option_b: b. They help identify responsibilities and collaborations
questions.option_c: c. They are used to write SQL
questions.explanation: CRC cards clarify class roles and interactions before coding.

questions.question: Which is an example of a control class in an online store?
questions.explanation: PaymentVerifier coordinates payment processing logic.

questions.question: In noun-verb analysis, which of these is a valid class and not an attribute or operation?
questions.explanation: Book represents an entity, whereas the others are attributes or operations.

questions.question: How are entity classes different from control classes?
questions.option_c: c. They store core system data
questions.explanation: Entity classes represent core domain data.

questions.question: What is the purpose of boundary classes in OOA?
questions.option_a: a. Connect users to the system
questions.explanation: Boundary classes handle interactions with external actors.

questions.question: In an e-commerce system, which of the following is an entity class?
questions.explanation: Product represents a core item of the domain model.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about analysis classes?
questions.option_a: a. Entity classes always interact with users
questions.option_b: b. Control classes store transaction data
questions.option_c: c. Boundary classes control object behavior
questions.option_d: d. Entity classes focus on core system data
questions.option_e: e. Control classes represent real-world objects
questions.explanation: Entity classes encapsulate the domain’s core information.
